sub_topic: The Hausdorff dimension of the Koch curve.
message_1: What is the Hausdorff dimension of the Koch curve generated by the recursive process of starting with an equilateral triangle of side 1 and iteratively replacing each straight line segment with four equal segments, with the resulting curve being the limit of the sequence of curves obtained in this way? Round your answer to two decimal places.
message_2:
The Hausdorff dimension of the Koch curve can be calculated using the formula:

D = log(N) / log(1 / S)

where D is the Hausdorff dimension, N is the number of self-similar pieces, and S is the scaling factor.

For the Koch curve, each straight line segment is replaced by four equal segments, so N = 4. The scaling factor S is 1/3, as each new segment is 1/3 the length of the original segment.

D = log(4) / log(1 / (1/3))
D = log(4) / log(3)

Using a calculator, we find that D â‰ˆ 1.26. So, the Hausdorff dimension of the Koch curve is approximately 1.26.
